report_title: Industry Report on Pet Hospice Services
executive_summary: Figures have been adjusted for inflation and are presented in 2024 currency. Households now consider pets as an integral part of the family more than ever. In recent years, a record-high pet ownership rate and shifting attitudes have boosted spending on pet care services, including hospice services. The broader pet care sector has flourished as pet owners sought the best for their pets. The industry's growth trajectory was not even disrupted by the COVID-19 pandemic. Despite work-from-home settings and travel restrictions, pet owners still utilized hospice services when needed. An unprecedented spike in pet ownership during the pandemic has shifted the industry's landscape, with demand for pet hospice services outpacing supply post-COVID. Pet owners' steep spending on pets has led industry-wide revenue to expand at a CAGR of 3.7% over the past five years, totaling an estimated $317.4 million, including an expected 0.8% increase in 2024.

current_performance.current_performance_point_description: The number of cats and dogs in the US surged in 2020 as COVID-19 lockdowns led consumers to look for companionship by adopting or buying a pet. More cats and dogs in the US translates to a greater need for the industry's services. Pet owners' willingness to spend on high-end pet care services currently characterizes the market. Pet owners are willing to spend on premium pet hospice care rather than take care of their older pets alone.

Revenue growth has helped hospice centers better handle fixed costs, like rent, utilities and other expenses. Prices have also increased ahead of input costs, and automation is reducing the impact of rising wage expenses.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: While consumers will continue to demand premium services for their pets, the price of key expenses will drop during the first half of the outlook period. Hospice service centers need to purchase a plethora of different pet products, from food to medicine to comfort items. Purchase costs for hospice centers have decreased slightly throughout 2024, enabling some struggling companies to lower prices and undercut competitors. Declining prices will temper revenue growth and make the industry more competitive.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: With Improving Economic Conditions, Demand for Pets Will Continue Rising
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: The rise in the number of pets will continue to boost demand for pet hospice services as per capita disposable income grows and economic conditions improve. With unemployment expected to decrease over the next five years and consumer spending expected to grow, more pet parents will increase spending on their pets.

industry_definition: Operators in this industry provide palliative and end-of-life care to animals, in both veterinary and household settings.

opportunities: High Performance Drivers - Number of pets (cats and dogs)

key_trends: The price of hospice services is a major form of competition. Hospice providers must ensure that prices are competitive so that customers remain loyal.
Pet hospice facilities benefit from being located near veterinarians and other animal clinics. By operating near these facilities, operators can minimize costs spent on acquiring key customers.

Revenue still climbed at the height of the pandemic. While demand for pet hospice services is typically tied to disposable income levels, people's love for their pets makes them feel like hospice services are a nondiscretionary expense, creating a greater need for the industry's services.

Growth will slow over the next five years. While demand will continue to expand, since many pets have recently been adopted during the pandemic, the rate of revenue increases will subside throughout 2029.
Pet hospice centers don't benefit from any specific government assistance. The industry does receive some indirect assistance from various related industry associations.

The increasing diversity of the population has improved demand for the industry's services. Younger demographics tend to utilize public hospice services more frequently as they are a lower-cost option, enabling the pets to live out its last moments with as much joy as possible.

Purchases consist of food, medicine, comfort supplies and toys. Families want their pet's last moments to be as joyful as possible, so operators must have efficient machinery and a plethora of quality products.
Labor is relied on for each service offering. Highly skilled workers are necessary for operations to move smoothly and ensure families' peace of mind with their pets.
Pet hospice services focus primarily on cats and dogs. That's why this section mainly focuses on hospice services for cats and dogs.

Pet owners between the ages of 55 and 64 are more likely to purchase high-profit services. This market's influence will likely increase as per capita disposable income levels are forecast to improve in the coming years.

market_segmentation.segment_description: This segment refers to pet owners between the ages of 25 to 29 years old. Since our pets typically have shorter life spans than humans, pet owners of all ages may experience bringing their pets to hospice service centers. However, younger pet owners typically get younger pets that then grow alongside them. As a result, the youngest segment accounts for the smallest share of revenue.

This segment refers to pet owners between the ages of 35 to 44 years old. This older segment represents a larger portion of industry revenue. However, it is still only the second smallest market in the pet hospice service industry.

This segment refers to pet owners between the ages of 45 and 54 years old. Pet owners in this segment make up the second-largest market. As pet owners age, their beloved pets age much quicker than themselves, resulting in increased demand for hospice services.

This segment refers to pet owners between the ages of 55 to 64 years old. Pet owners in this segment represent the largest market. As pet owners and their pets reach this age, many are already way past their primes and can be considered very senior. Most pets that live for a decade or more are typically classified as elderly.

This segment refers to pet owners aged 65 and older. Although pet owners are continuing to get older, many of their pets are not able to make it this long. As a result, this market's share of revenue decreased

products_and_services.product_description: Dog hospice services involve the specialized and compassionate care for terminally ill dogs. This can be done privately or in a public hospice center. Public hospice services are always the most affordable, as there are multiple pets in one facility. People who choose private care end up purchasing more products, such as specialized attention that can't be done in public settings.

Cat hospice services involve the specialized and compassionate care for terminally ill cats. As with dog hospice services, this can also be done privately or in a public facility. The only difference between dog and cat hospice services is typically the type of care and medications needed.

Bird, reptiles and other pet hospice services involve the specialized and compassionate care for all other terminally ill pets. Private hospice services are typically the most profitable product offering, as there are many add-ons consumers can purchase for private care.

tier_1_suppliers: Hospices & Palliative Care Centers in the US

demand_determinants.determinant_title: The number of pets measures the number of household cats and dogs in the United States.
demand_determinants.determinant_description: As more people get pets, demand for pet care industries, such as the Pet Hospice industry, increases. Additionally, as people increase spending on their pets, industry demand is also likely to rise. A rise in the number of pets represents a potential opportunity for the industry.

basis_points.basis_title: The price of hospice services is a major form of competition
basis_points.basis_description: Hospice providers must ensure that prices are competitive so that customers remain loyal.
Pet hospice facilities benefit from being located near veterinarians and other animal clinics. By operating near these facilities, operators can minimize costs spent on acquiring key customers.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Wages are the Largest Expense Here
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Wages and other labor expenditures are the most significant expense for operators, much like in other professional services industries.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: Innovation lies in the digitization of services

volatility_points.volatility_description: Certain types of hospice services come with a higher price tag than other alternatives, so high per capita disposable income is essential for sales.

technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Innovation lies in the digitization of services

FAQs.question: What are the key points about revenue volatility?
FAQs.answer: Disposable income can be volatile, which impacts demand for higher-priced hospice services. Consumers with more disposable income are more likely to request private hospice services with higher profit margins.

FAQs.question: What are the key points about regulation and policy?
FAQs.answer: The industry faces moderate and steady regulation.

FAQs.question: What are the key points about industry assistance?
FAQs.answer: The industry receives moderate and steady assistance.
